data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Faith is a passionate intuition.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: That though the radiance which was once so bright be now forever taken from my sight. Though nothing can bring back the hour of splendor in the grass, glory in the flower. We will grieve not, rather find strength in what remains behind.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Our birth is but a sleep and a forgetting. Not in entire forgetfulness, and not in utter nakedness, but trailing clouds of glory do we come.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: How does the Meadow flower its bloom unfold? Because the lovely little flower is free down to its root, and in that freedom bold.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: The human mind is capable of excitement without the application of gross and violent stimulants; and he must have a very faint perception of its beauty and dignity who does not know this.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Golf is a day spent in a round of strenuous idleness.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: The things which I have seen I now can see no more.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: The mind that is wise mourns less for what age takes away; than what it leaves behind.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: To begin, begin.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: The best portion of a good man's life is his little, nameless, unremembered acts of kindness and of love.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: What is pride? A rocket that emulates the stars.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Poetry is the spontaneous overflow of powerful feelings: it takes its origin from emotion recollected in tranquility.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Getting and spending, we lay waste our powers.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: But an old age serene and bright, and lovely as a Lapland night, shall lead thee to thy grave.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: For I have learned to look on nature, not as in the hour of thoughtless youth, but hearing oftentimes the still, sad music of humanity.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Wisdom is oftentimes nearer when we stoop than when we soar.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Suffering is permanent, obscure and dark, And shares the nature of infinity.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: To me the meanest flower that blows can give thoughts that do often lie too deep for tears.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: With an eye made quiet by the power of harmony, and the deep power of joy, we see into the life of things.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Pictures deface walls more often than they decorate them.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: What we need is not the will to believe, but the wish to find out.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: The flower that smells the sweetest is shy and lowly.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Fill your paper with the breathings of your heart.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Rapine, avarice, expense, This is idolatry; and these we adore; Plain living and high thinking are no more.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: In modern business it is not the crook who is to be feared most, it is the honest man who doesn't know what he is doing.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: The ocean is a mighty harmonist.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: When from our better selves we have too long been parted by the hurrying world, and droop. Sick of its business, of its pleasures tired, how gracious, how benign is solitude.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: The child is father of the man.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: I listened, motionless and still; And, as I mounted up the hill, The music in my heart I bore, Long after it was heard no more.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: A multitude of causes unknown to former times are now acting with a combined force to blunt the discriminating powers of the mind, and unfitting it for all voluntary exertion to reduce it to a state of almost savage torpor.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Life is divided into three terms - that which was, which is, and which will be. Let us learn from the past to profit by the present, and from the present, to live better in the future.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Not without hope we suffer and we mourn.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Nature never did betray the heart that loved her.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: One impulse from a vernal wood May teach you more of man, Of moral evil and of good, Than all the sages can.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: The world is too much with us; late and soon, getting and spending, we lay waste our powers: Little we see in Nature that is ours.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: Come forth into the light of things, let nature be your teacher.

data.author: William Wordsworth
data.en: That best portion of a man's life, his little, nameless, unremembered acts of kindness and love.
